text:
Hey julians. I found this one a little tricky to fix. I have a rosenbrock function that takes 2 values and returns 1 value. So I was trying to run this as a comprehension, but I am getting out a (401,401) array, instead of a (401,1) array. Here is the code.
```x = -2:0.01:2
y = -2:0.01:2
rosenbrock(x,p) =  (p[1] - x[1])^2 + p[2] * (x[2] - x[1]^2)^2
z = [rosenbrock([i, j], p) for i=x, j=y]```
But I keep getting out a (401,401) array instead of a 401,1 array. Now it makes sense that the comprehension is iterating over the `i` and `j` dimensions, so there are probably repeated entries. But still I was not clear on how to fix this. I tried parenthesis `(i=x, j=y)`.

Alternatively, if I do.
```z2 = map((x, y) -> rosenbrock([x,y], p), x, y)```
Then it works out fine and I get a (401, 1) array,

elements.text: Hey julians. I found this one a little tricky to fix. I have a rosenbrock function that takes 2 values and returns 1 value. So I was trying to run this as a comprehension, but I am getting out a (401,401) array, instead of a (401,1) array. Here is the code.
But I keep getting out a (401,401) array instead of a 401,1 array. Now it makes sense that the comprehension is iterating over the
dimensions, so there are probably repeated entries. But still I was not clear on how to fix this. I tried parenthesis
z2 = map((x, y) -> rosenbrock([x,y], p), x, y)
Then it works out fine and I get a (401, 1) array,

text: Can we cross post this publicly to <https://discourse.julialang.org|Discourse> for further visibility? React with :bridge: on the message above to approve. <https://github.com/JuliaCommunity/SlackBridge/blob/main/README.md#faq|More info here>

Success, it has been cross posted <https://discourse.julialang.org/t/57110| to Discourse>. Keep and eye out on Discourse for responses and please add an answer there once you are satisfied with the solution so others can benefit as well. Happy debugging!
your code doesn't run because `p` is not defined in `z=`

```julia> z = [rosenbrock(pair, [1,1]) for pair in zip(x,y)]```
or
```rosenbrock.(zip(x,y), Ref([1,1]))```
`[1,1]` is the dummy `p` since I'm not sure what it should be

elements.text: julia> z = [rosenbrock(pair, [1,1]) for pair in zip(x,y)]
since I'm not sure what it should be

text: <@UH8A351DJ> Yes, sorry. I forgot to include `p` when posting the code. But using `zip` makes sense. That seems to be what I was missing. Thanks so much for finding the solution here.

elements.text: Yes, sorry. I forgot to include
when posting the code. But using
makes sense. That seems to be what I was missing. Thanks so much for finding the solution here.

text: Hey <@UDDSTBX19>, if you were able to find an answer here on Slack, please cross post it to Discourse via the link above. Thank you!
Some more clarification: `[ (x,y) for x=1:10, y=1:10 ]` does a cartesian iteration over both collections, that's why you get a matrix out

elements.text: does a cartesian iteration over both collections, that's why you get a matrix out
